data.title: RolandNote.com: The Ultimate Country Music Database
data.meta_description: The RolandNote Country Music Database is a constantly updated source for everything you want to know about country music history. From Jimmie Rodgers to The Judds, from Gene Autry to Garth Brooks, from The Carter Family to Carrie Underwood, RolandNote.com supplies endless biographical data and trivia. It's a quick resource not only for the front-line artists, but also the producers, songwriters and musicians - fiddlers, guitarists, drummers and Dobro players - that helped establish hillbilly, bluegrass, western swing and honky-tonk music. But it's not just about the people in country music. It's a fascinating tool to find details about such radio shows as the Grand Ole Opry and 'The Louisiana Hayride'; important sites such as the Ryman Auditorium, RCA Studio B and the Country Music Hall of Fame; major movies and TV shows such as 'Urban Cowboy,' 'Hee Haw,' 'Reba' and 'CMT Crossroads'; and the histories of significant albums and songs, such as Lee Ann Womack's 'I Hope You Dance,' Shania Twain's 'Come On Over,' Johnny Cash's 'Folsom Prison Blues' and Hank Williams' 'I'm So Lonesome I Could Cry.' Created by music journalist Tom Roland, it's an essential virtual stomping ground for anyone who loves country music, be it a radio program director, a Music Row professional or a devoted country fan.
data.text:
Mar 26, 1950

Ronnie McDowell is born in Fountain Head, Tennessee. Following his 1977 tribute to Elvis Presley, "The King Is Gone," he reaps more than a dozen Top 10 hits through 1987, including "Older Women" and "You're Gonna Ruin My Bad Reputation"

Sep 8, 1972

Ronnie and Karan McDowell, a former Dairy Queen waitress, are married

Jun 9, 1976

Ronnie McDowell conducts his first Nashville recording session for Scorpion Records at RCA Studio B

Aug 16, 1977

Within hours of hearing that Elvis Presley has died, Ronnie McDowell writes a tribute, "The King Is Gone," destined to become his first hit

Aug 18, 1977

Ronnie McDowell records an Elvis Presley tribute, "The King Is Gone," at Nashville's Music City Recorders

Aug 21, 1977

Just five days after Elvis Presley's death, Scorpion Records releases a tribute record, Ronnie McDowell's "The King Is Gone"

Aug 26, 1977

Just 10 days after Elvis Presley's death, Ronnie McDowell makes his Grand Ole Opry debut, singing "The King Is Gone" in tribute

Sep 8, 1977

Ronnie McDowell claims the only gold single of his career, for his tribute to Elvis Presley, "The King Is Gone"

Sep 8, 1977

As they celebrate their fifth wedding anniversary, Karan McDowell gives Ronnie McDowell an Elvis Presley pendant. Just three weeks earlier, he recorded his Presley tribute "The King Is Gone"

Oct 21, 1977

Ronnie McDowell sings "The King Is Gone" on "The Midnight Special." The lineup also features Elvin Bishop, Van Morrison and Crystal Gayle, who offers "Don't It Make My Brown Eyes Blue" and "Ready For The Times To Get Better"

Displaying : 1 - 10 of 54 / Page 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6
